data.title: 'Justified: City Primeval' Star Adelaide Clemens on Her Favorite Behind
data.meta_description: After her character's bombshell exit, the actress spills on what drew her to the role and Ôªøwhy working with Timothy Olyphant is "like acting gymnastics."
data.text:
We're seven episodes in to FX's Justified: City Primeval, the one-off reboot of the TV classic Justified based on . And [üö®spoilerüö®] the most recent episode came with a bombshell: Sandy, played by Adelaide Clemens, betrays Clement to U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens before making a swift departure from Detroit (she is still on the wrong side of the Albanians after all).

If you‚Äôre wondering why Adelaide looks so familiar, you‚Äôve probably seen the Australian actress before. Her TV credits include FX‚Äôs Under the Banner of Heaven, CBS‚Äôs Tommy, and a memorable turn as Tawney Talbot in the acclaimed Southern gothic series Rectify on AMC+. She has also starred in Max's Parade‚Äôs End as well as several indie movies, including 2022‚Äôs The Swearing Jar with Patrick J. Adams (aka Mike Ross on Suits).

Justified: City Primeval is a departure from the first series in that the central character, Raylan, is not in the book , but rather the plot has been reimagined as a Raylan story. Still, the relationship between Sandy and Clement (played by Boyd Holbrook) recalls the dynamic between Ava and Boyd Crowder in the original six seasons: a smart, beautiful woman inadvisably drawn to an unhinged yet charismatic criminal.

While we wait for the dramatic conclusion of the limited series, which airs on FX on Tuesday, August 29, at 10 p.m. ET/PT and streams next-day on , we‚Äôre sharing our recent interview with Adelaide. Read on for what makes her character tick, her experiences behind the scenes, and why working with star and executive producer Timothy Olyphant (Raylan) is "like acting gymnastics."

Disclaimer: The following interview with Adelaide Clemens took place on June 28 before the SAG-AFTRA strike.

In Justified: City Primeval, you play Sandy Stanton, girlfriend to outlaw Clement Mansell. What drew you to the role?

‚ÄúWhen I read the script, it was just so exciting. It‚Äôs a pulpy show. It‚Äôs fun. It‚Äôs like all my favorite movies growing up. I loved Alabama [Patricia Arquette] in True Romance [1993] and Lula [Laura Dern] in Wild at Heart [1990]. They‚Äôre the dream characters that, as a young girl, I wanted to play. So this was that opportunity, and I‚Äôd never really had that opportunity to really flesh out a character like Sandy. She‚Äôs sexy. She‚Äôs vain. She‚Äôs fun. She‚Äôs working guys, and she‚Äôs a criminal [laughs]. It was fun.

‚ÄúThen, I saw who was attached. Tim Olyphant and I did a play together before in New York [Hold on to Me Darling directed by Kenneth Lonergan]. He was incredible in that, and he‚Äôs a dear friend of mine. I had an instinct‚Äîand my instinct was correct‚Äîthat it was a good group of people.‚Äù

What is Sandy thinking being with Clement‚Äîand what finally makes her leave?

‚ÄúI think she‚Äôs in a certain amount of denial about how bad things have gotten. All the way through, Sandy has no intention of leaving Clement. She is completely in love with him. Whether that is a healthy relationship, we all have our opinions on that, but to her this is the kind of love she knows, the kind of love she grew up with, so I don‚Äôt think she has any intention of leaving. Once the veil of denial comes down and she starts to see Clement for who he is, I mean, he‚Äôs really unwell‚Äîhe‚Äôs a sociopath with mania and impulse control issues, and he has a violence in him that really gets the better of him.

‚ÄúThere are certain boundaries that she has in the relationship, though‚Äîthere‚Äôs that scene where she tells him, ‚ÄúGo brush your teeth.‚Äù She has standards, and she is a woman who could get pretty much anyone, so I think it‚Äôs healthy that she knows that about herself. I think the heartbreaking thing is she really wants it to work out with Clement.‚Äù

Justified‚Äîthe original and the reboot‚Äîis known for those moments of dry humor when the characters are in serious danger. Does the humor carry over behind the scenes?

‚ÄúOh my god, constantly. Everyone is so fun. Quentin Tarantino was supposed to be part of the project as a potential director [ultimately, it didn‚Äôt happen]; that was helpful to me in understanding the tone of the show. It‚Äôs almost like everyone‚Äôs pretending the stakes are really low, but they‚Äôre actually really high. It‚Äôs an ironic sort of approach. But Tim is hilarious, and Boyd Holbrook is so wonderful to work with. [Showrunners and executive producers] Michael Dinner and Dave Andron were so funny, and everyone‚Äîit was the best group of people.‚Äù

What was your most memorable moment on set?

‚ÄúTim is so fun. It‚Äôs like acting gymnastics because he comes up with things at the very last minute for you to play‚Äînot for his character but for you. So we were doing that scene in episode two where Sandy answers the door in her bathrobe, and Tim was like, 'What if she‚Äôs sick?' It was a seven-page scene where I suddenly had to play sick and figure out how to do that. So part of the panic that you see Sandy going through in that scene is actually just my genuine panic about, like, is this going to look insane? But that was really fun.

‚ÄúAlso, Boyd and I, we just had the best time. I think this often happens that the more anxiety-inducing the scene is, the more fun you tend to have. Maybe it was all that nervous energy that we had on set, but we would just laugh the whole day.‚Äù

When Sandy leaves Detroit, she indicates to Raylan she'll be turning her life around. Do you think she'll follow through?

‚ÄúI think Sandy is a good person, and I don‚Äôt think she wants anyone to die, which is why‚Äîthis line was ad-libbed on the day‚Äîwhen Clement is about to crush Skender‚Äôs [Alexander Pobutsky] leg, she says, ‚ÄòBabe, why don‚Äôt you just punch him in the face.‚Äô She‚Äôs a best-case scenario type of person. She‚Äôs hoping for the best in every single one of these criminal ventures.

‚ÄúI hope that she does that, and perhaps the terror and the fear that she‚Äôs been living in this relationship with Mansell might be enough to keep her that way. I think it‚Äôs challenging for people who are attracted to dangerous personalities stay out of trouble, but I hope for the best.‚Äù
